426B335C889F439C8F68E8D3BD37DFC4.description: Recognize that electrical devices need energy to work.

96E2B469753248CA89B18876AA4FA2A9.description: Recognize that a hot object can make a cold object warm when they touch.

64D4E25168854E3281FACE5D360F1D79.description: Recognize that energy can change forms, such as electricity produces light and heat in a lamp.

43B4DD48B5484532A395F797000C5913.description: Recognize what happens to the temperature when heat is added.

246E54BD8EF945F9BF7B986286BDCE54.description: Identify examples of the predictable movement of heat, such as hot air rises and heat transfers from hot to cold objects.

F8A008098DCC44A8AF82F55F6F17781A.description: Recognize that one form of energy can change to other forms of energy, such as solar panels change light into electricity.

4EC71EA84B0A43168E85AB0A36ADB928.description: Identify that when heat is added or taken away, a temperature change occurs.

ED1D3AE99F214A82B8D76096FB0E7CFE.description: Match light and sound to their sources.

480B61A642C542B28C05AA8B6D1EB53B.description: Recognize primary colors of a rainbow.

D81BE4ADBA8D42EB9EAA8762A4EA231E.description: Recognize that sound and light travel.

8AC01BE83B8D467CA8C9B772CF9F3BFF.description: Recognize that light can be reflected.

C5CF086673C54A509C817FDA41A83ACE.description: Recognize that white (visible) light contains many colors, such as viewed with a prism or rainbow.

C8183AE4C09443E0A9E66C0760A437D1.description: Identify that light and sound travel in wave patterns.

E08DB9F6C55F4F82AC920BA12AC416D3.description: Recognize that light can be reflected or absorbed.

BCE172D0415C43AF96083A8C35E444A3.description: Identify that white (visible) light has many colors, such as when viewed with a prism.

F3C0243C481D4BCDA9EC27B6B117950A.description: Recognize a model of a common activity.

5653439D01C64206B4D55991FBC7DFB0.description: Recognize that people use science to solve problems.

A3FA7076CA2C4C7EA3F86F56F0D5EDCB.description: Recognize a benefit of using a model to explain how things work.

5C861E2424B84ECE840EEB9A9BC76881.description: Recognize that scientific theories and laws are supported by evidence.

F8FFC3C03842457881665517FD88BBF8.description: Identify a benefit of using a model to explain how things work.

5B4F93C952CF4837A13E05E76D2B0B12.description: Identify that scientific theories are explanations and laws describe relationships, and both are supported by evidence.

E0AA089DE77347249140A392BDE0A267.description: The Role of Theories, Laws, Hypotheses, and Models

29855E73088347F1B7BB6F8F0B8ED258.description: Recognize an example of a change in scientific knowledge based on new evidence.

C72AEE02D70742539FBA6C0730A3A788.description: Identify an example of a change in scientific knowledge based on new evidence or new interpretations.

78FFC33B80434CF482C17E6FAA10FE11.description: Associate objects and activities with science.

FDF503E568F44B5390F29A711195C981.description: Associate objects and activities with science.

79E73D095E674042B186AFE10383F27C.description: Recognize observable changes in a simple experiment, such as plant growth.

BB21F038F3A64B67AB2B41498188D80F.description: Recognize a problem related to the seventh grade curriculum, observe and explore objects and activities, and recognize a solution.

DB54FDC0F18D444E959D25D1E82E7183.description: Recognize that scientific knowledge is based on evidence and observations.

09668C9ACF4849B99C634D6FD9E32894.description: Recognize that science includes different areas, such as life science, earth and space science, and physical science.

839F94D1A4E24BBBA613B35B3678A3DB.description: Recognize a question that can be answered by scientific investigation, such as can a plant grow without sunlight?

1680817E56E54740BC77BC1425F29C57.description: Recognize what is tested in a simple experiment (dependent variable).

DF1E6275807D435D96D7EA568644FB98.description: Recognize a problem from the seventh grade curriculum, use materials to gather information, conduct a simple experiment, and record and share results.

527829FD53124B76AE326BD83B253E24.description: Identify that scientific knowledge is based on a large body of evidence and observations.

2AFBA084E2234A54831D20B59B96A992.description: Identify ways that science can be used to study different areas, such as life science, earth and space science, and physical science.

E13453AF94AD4591A22229D8706C4AF4.description: Identify questions that can be answered by scientific investigation, such as can a plant grow without sunlight?

CB05A66E572C4B758FEBBE5935E1BAE2.description: Recognize the relationship between the end product (dependent variable) and in the input (independent variable) in an experiment.

19A5522B135245C1BC4E73A64757181C.description: Identify a problem from the seventh grade curriculum, use reference materials to gather information, carry out an experiment, collect and record data, and report results.

98FB24D3F89945AC8B093EE5805475B7.description: Recognize what happens when animals don’t get food and water.

4D82F3F0CC054058BA99AB1A3077D6F8.description: Recognize a mutual relationship between people and other living things.

BCCA0AA7DCCD4971AFABDED7321AFACB.description: Recognize that humans eat vegetables and fruits (plants) and meat (animals).

793C0450924A4DD6BE2C31BA50833BEC.description: Identify how a lack of food, water, or shelter affects plants and animals in their habitats.

289CA0D8AFB44CD186B7E5AB5947F568.description: Recognize how living things affect each other in their habitat (ecosystem).

04955773ABEE4163BD63EF79BE40545F.description: Identify different types of consumers in a food chain, including animals that eat plants, animals that eat other animals, and animals that eat plants and animals.

638B6C08AED64080939C695AEA9F1DE3.description: Recognize that living things compete with each other to get the things they need to live in their local environment.

73039E50027C4115BBF32735B08C3003.description: Describe how organisms interact with other organisms in an ecosystem to help each other (mutualism), to obtain food (predation), and to benefit at the expense of the other (parasitism).

6E3FCCCD353A4B8797D0D56531C56715.description: Identify that in a simple food chain, energy transfers from the Sun to plants (producers), to animals (consumers), and to organisms that cause decay (decomposers).

FC2776D896C04FB3828D9A601F1D272A.description: Recognize common products, such as medicine, developed through science.

9B9EFB2F9D9C4A849F0C48EC56DC81C8.description: Recognize that children are born from two parents.

77BD13065940416D99B8FB239A8B0BEF.description: Recognize a characteristic passed from parents to self, such as eye color.

FAFB98B665AD4234B233150937B7FF2B.description: Recognize that science (biotechnology) has been used to develop new products for use in daily life.

C2199AD6E5754CC980962D148777B218.description: Recognize that animals, including humans, inherit some characteristics from one parent and some from the other.

E64A22F8707F4040BDE9521F7D5D1703.description: Recognize that offspring have similar characteristics to parents.

DD6BEFCA37F64696AE4829E8DC679861.description: Recognize that science processes (biotechnology) have been used to develop new foods and medicines.

04A6B546D0F1455183B62C3AEDA81191.description: Explain that offspring receive half their genes from each parent in sexual reproduction.

3CB453ACFF0041AC9A7541397BED2748.description: Recognize that it is possible to predict whether a person is likely to inherit a particular trait from parents.

33EB40F54D6A4E4C9F3468584E368FAE.description: Explain that some characteristics are passed from parent to child (inherited).

9F1E362D50704804A742C29C5A8CB18B.description: Recognize a personal characteristic, such as hair color, that is different from the parents.

0ACFBD511EAD4E97A036621075ECE061.description: Recognize that living things can die.

61D3F53C29F4437E86CAB31BD0FB513C.description: Recognize that some plants and animals no longer exist (are extinct).

F7FD763E154B4F45A13FE10113331618.description: Recognize that common plants or animals have special features that enable them to live in their environment, such as a as a fish has gills so it can live underwater.

D192711AA4174414920E2122E46F4AD0.description: Identify fossils as parts of animals and plants that are no longer alive.

591C83D096EE4894A1587365972B8B34.description: Recognize that physical characteristics of living things are adapted to deal with the conditions of the environment, such as skin color or gills on a fish.

4A0E9E4201144929B6A4C4A989D96EE8.description: Recognize that fossils help people learn about living things that lived a very long time ago.

2FB8227EC4854DA9BE986E5529B5347E.description: Diversity and Evolution of Living Organisms

1A073669A92C4B4B99C59AB52D809832.description: Distinguish between clean and dirty water.

BA850C50700F47969BCD4961B24E715B.description: Recognize that ground on the Earth’s surface changes over time.

56A06B5CEF9F4B73942E44FB0FCC1EFA.description: Discriminate between surface features of ground on Earth, such as rocky/sandy, flat/hilly, rough/smooth, or solid/liquid.

27A1B050145940A69EDE7EBFC035B944.description: Recognize the ground as the outer surface (crust) of Earth.

9F8859AC68A0417CB1463761B2C16877.description: Recognize that polluting the air and water can harm Earth.

A7E02449E3F64E0D9D84853C93B64BCA.description: Recognize the effects of earthquakes and volcanoes.

E8857068E98E48D5BDFFA480E815240F.description: Recognize that fossils are remains or imprints of living things from long ago.

BEE157558D5B4741839F94D53A97A728.description: Recognize that mountains change size and shape over a long period of time.

05A67BA6E8714B28AACCE3B5497387BE.description: Recognize that the surface of Earth is called the crust.

2EDF1E90FD54452FB9426B64C956819C.description: Recognize that humans have had an impact on Earth, such as polluting the air and water and expanding urban areas and road systems.

B26D6C03D0384863B19F81CFBBB625B8.description: Identify physical evidence, such as fossils and sedimentary rock, which show how Earth has changed over a very long period of time.

2D699C12A0FE446BA57D7DE256D7E08B.description: Demonstrate how older rock layers are deposited at the bottom before younger layers (Law of Superposition).

0834DFD4BBF3471B842E682F80B27B5D.description: Recognize that slow changes, such as mountain-building, and fast changes, such as volcanic eruptions, are caused by shifts below Earth’s surface.

7C472304A053405BB8BFC0255BE2CD69.description: Identify that Earth has three layers (crust, mantle, and core) and describe the inside (core) as the hottest layer.
